Yes and no.

Yes, it was true that between 1347 and 1351 a series of epidemics reduced the population dramatically in many places in Europe.

No… the estimates vary widely, depending on what you include. To me, a much more reasonable one is the 30-40% in Europe alone. Of the 8-10 million population of Christendom in 1300, half was dead in 1351 with a total population loss of about 50%. That’s the best range I can give.

For reasons described here, the 1300s in Europe were far from perfect. Population recovery took centuries. The Middle Ages was not a Golden Age of Western Europe. But, compared to the rest of the world, Christianity did much better. After 1351, the Black Death raged but did not eradicate Western Europe. As noted often, in the 3rd pandemic of the plague (1894-1901) up to 10 million people were killed, mostly in Asia and Egypt. Again it was not a global disaster, although the 1865-1899 pandemic did rage again in Europe. The overall human toll of the Black Death for the entire world has never been estimated.

The Black Death did not hit Africa or China to any great extent. Indeed, while plague hit Spain, many years later it did not reach England. Yes, there were losses in the Islamic world, but they were relatively small.

It should be noted that the Black Death did hit North America, but it was not an epidemic. It killed a large number of animals (mainly squirrels) but not humans.

Sarah Luebke August 7, 2013 at 10:49 pm
I just came across this website, and it has some interesting details on the Black Death. You can access it at: http://fate-history.wikidot.com/black-death

I guess there will never be one source that gives exact figures.

The statistics we know today come from a study by Cohn and Angold in 2002 as well as other sources such as the Encyclopaedia Britannica and Wikipedia.

The study by Cohn and Angold did extensive analysis on the data from several contemporary documents written by chroniclers. Many deaths were not recorded, such as those that happened at home far from the city. In some cases, chroniclers noted a great decline in the population, but in other cases, a mild decline or no decline at all, even in villages where the plague is known to have been present.

Their estimates on the percentage of Europeans who were killed by the bubonic plague vary. The range they give is from 30% to 60%, which includes the entire Western European population from 1348 to 1500. Other estimates place it as high as 80%. The percentage for Russia is significantly less, since it is known that the Russian populace was immune. The Black Death hit Russia by 550 AD, and it had been present since.

When you look at it region by region, the 14th century Black Death was far more devastating in Western Europe. The Black Death hit England very early (24 Oct 1348), while it came later to France (1349). Russia had no losses, and even China did not lose any.

It did hit Africa, but not heavily. West Africa, being near the trade routes with Europe, lost significantly. By 2100 AD, the Yersinia bacteria were no longer present (but it may resurface in a few centuries; we have seen a Yersinia outbreak before in 1894 on Saipan Island).

The Black Death struck the Muslim world several times, and the population decline was significant in Spain and northern Africa. As mentioned earlier, it never reached Egypt until about 1509, and it did not hit India until 1817 (see Wikipedia article on "Black Death in India").

The Black Death could be thought of as an invasion, where the people of a nation fell back and gave up resistance, or surrendered to the invading bacteria. By far, the worst loss occurred in Western Europe from roughly 1350 to 1450, but the human toll in China was estimated at 45% at that time.

To get a rough idea on how the population of worldwide changed, note that the total world population in 14th century AD was about 120 million. The European population then was about 90 million (45% of the world total), and it declined to about 30 million in the Black Death aftermath. That is certainly a significant loss. Against this decline of Europeans, the African population remained relatively intact, whereas the Muslim populations suffered significant losses.

A comparison of 1308 and 1396 indicates that some population recovery went on in most parts of Western Europe. It is not clear what percentage of population was restored.

The population of worldwide after centuries of plague epidemics has continued to improve since the plague period, with the world population estimated at about 1.5 billion in 1804. Today, the estimated population of the world (in 2013) is 7,232,296,500. This has obviously been helped by better communications, better transportation, a decline in famines, and improved sanitation.

When you read about the Black Death, you will frequently read about it as a mass-murder epidemic, but that was not its purpose. It was an attempt on nature's part to reduce the population.

In the past few centuries, the Black Death has not returned. It did return to Russia (by 1894-1901), but it did not bring mass death (about 1 million fatalities). It is important that we remember that this was a natural disaster that nature brought upon itself.

Matt:

Yes, that would be the most obvious explanation for that. I think the word “mass” in the English language refers to a large number of something. There are other words, such as “multitude” and “throng.” I think of “mass” as the plural form of “much”. As I understand it, a “multitude” is a large number of people. So “mass” should not be used to describe a relatively small number of people.

In recent years there have been a number of pandemics which caused many deaths, many of them directly attributed to an infection. In the US, we had a “flu” epidemic in 1918. Somehow this flu spread from people traveling aboard ocean liners, and as they disembarked, they infected other people in the various ports of call. Within a few days a “pandemic” was declared and the flu “swept” the country causing over 50 million deaths at home and over 1 million deaths at home and abroad. There was not enough of a vaccine to counteract it, although there was a vaccine produced later.

Many times in recent months, we will hear about a major flu epidemic, and every time the “flu” spreads, we are told that it is a new strain, and the vaccine we get will not be able to fight it. The problem here is that the “flu” is H1N1, the Swine flu, and every person who thinks that H1N1 is a new strain, a new virus, is not telling the truth. H1N1 has been around for about a hundred years and for ten years now. It is a typical annual occurrence. The Swine flu that first appeared two winters ago was an unusual swine virus, but it did not kill 12,000 people in Mexico, one fifth of the population, or kill over a hundred thousand people in the US.

In 1988 we had a major outbreak of HIV and AIDS. This came shortly after the AIDS epidemic hit some of the hardest hit areas in Africa, and although many people around the world died from HIV and AIDS, there was no global pandemic, no worldwide epidemic. Many Americans thought the AIDS epidemic was affecting them, although their deaths were often called “suicides”. This was not a pandemic from the common epidemic definition. It was a pandemic as defined by the US military, which had a plan to evacuate military people that were AIDS positive from the military. The US military is often described as being first. In reality they always follow what the civilian authorities had done, but they were the military that first tried to deal with the AIDS epidemic on a military base.

Here are two websites that address this issue:

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swine_flu
- https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/285510.php

As for H5N1, H1N1, H3N2, H7N9, H9N2, and all the other H (types) variants, we have all known about them since we saw them in people that died in Hong Kong. We have also known about swine influenza since the Spanish Influenza. Although we have no official history of swine influenza, people in China and many other countries have known about swine influenza since 1000 AD. Swine influenza (H3N2 is the current type) can be traced to pigs. When we hear that someone is dying from a pandemic, we must always ask what type of pandemic it is, what type of virus infects human beings and causes fatal infections, a virus that we have seen in people, a virus that is H1N1, H3N2, H5N1, or H9N2? We must remember that some viruses just kill people, not cause pandemics.

I have not heard in 10 years, nor in the last ten years, anyone talking about a “pandemic” flu (or flu pandemic). What has always killed people was a “flu” epidemic, not a pandemic. This has been repeated throughout history. You will never hear about smallpox being a pandemic when it killed about 300 million people worldwide from about 1500 to 1980 AD

Hey Jim,

I know I will receive hundreds of emails/comments, but this was just a little addition to an article on the pandemics that had hit America.

(Hi John – the article is on the page with a link to our site wiki history. If you go to that page, scroll down and look under “Plague Outbreaks in American History: 1662”.

The Black Death was one of the more devastating pandemics in the history of the world.

It was said to have killed about 30% to 60% of Europe’s population.

The “plague” was caused by the Yersinia Pestis bacteria that caused the Black Death pandemic of the Middle Ages. The symptoms included blood and necrosis as it entered the blood through the digestive tract (buboes, or bulging swelling). The pulmonary version can cause the sudden death of individuals (as was said to happen to King Edward VI of England). Pneumonic plague would have to be taken through the air.

Yersinia Pestis is still around today in several locations. In the Pacific Islands, the Black Death was still a problem in 1918, killing 50% or more of the population. An outbreak of the bubonic plague at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal Laboratory in 1951 killed 2,274 mice which could kill humans, if it were to enter the body.

It is important to realize that in Europe in the Middle Ages, about half of the population died (or about 60% in some areas). There are two reasons for this.

1. No vaccinations existed.

2. Infectious material such as blood and plaque (where it would enter skin or flesh) was often washed off the streets of cities.

People died from blood poisoning and it would only take a few days to cause the buboes to form and the victim would die in a week or two. (A more modern version of an infectious disease is Tuberculosis.)

In the Middle Ages, it was also possible (in very rare cases) for an individual to die suddenly and without warning from the diseases. Pneumonic and septicemic plagues were like that.

Europe had large cities during this period such as Rome and Paris. (Rome had 1-2 million people – Paris about half that number.)

The Black Death happened in Europe in waves. In about six years, the plague hit Europe twice (about 7 years apart) and then killed about 50% of the population in a single wave/pandemic (and some places double that much).

Diseases like smallpox and influenza did not affect this period. They were either not known about yet (influenza) or not present (smallpox and measles).

Those 50 years when the Black Death struck Europe twice had some impact on the population. The population would decrease because of the high death rate and the Black Plague, or some other disease coming at the same time as a famine. A famine would often take the lives of 25%-50% of the population.

Another factor was that people would run away from the plague. This would cause a smaller population of survivors.

Because of the smaller population, there would be an increased number of food and job opportunities as many died (such as the nobility).

Some countries or small regions would get hit by the Black Death more than once – such as Italy. Certain areas would have some impact from the disease.

With the smaller population, there were fewer farms and more people were able to feed themselves (as well as grow their own gardens).

This caused there to be a much greater surplus of money at the bottom of the pyramid/social ladder. There were also fewer nobles and lords who owned the land, or there was a push for the peasants to rent the land from the land owners.

This was a time of rapid change in Europe.

Europe’s population had been around half a billion during the Middle Ages. By the end of the 1400s, there were more than 30 million people in Western Europe (more than France). It took two centuries for Europe to climb up to the lower numbers (60%) (and they climbed down a bit too).

Europe (and China) did not have the technology of antibiotics until about a hundred years ago (penicillin in 1940). These bubonic and pneumonic pandemics had an impact on life in Europe. It killed people, it caused famine, and it changed the face of Europe and had an impact on the lives of surviving people.

As we go through the Black Plague and the pandemics that killed people, we need to keep in mind that people at that point in time would have thought of the plague as a punishment from God.

They wanted a scapegoat. The poor were looked down upon. The rich and powerful got off scot-free, but by killing off the lower classes, they had less people to have to tax. The middle class also got off fairly easy.

(This was when people’s power over others was at it’s greatest. They were able to manipulate most anyone and most anything.)

The Black Plague was a horrific disease that was caused by Yersinia Pestis. It was very infectious. A new pandemic could hit Europe at any time and kill 50% or more of the population (about half the population at that point in time).

There were other pandemics that came at different times (or even at the same time as the plague) that killed a fair percentage of the population (25%+).

1) Justinian’s Plague – 541: This was the first time Black Plague was reported. It was a mild infection (which caused fewer deaths from the disease), but it was still a worldwide pandemic. The Emperor of Rome was dead within three years (550).

2) Yellow Fever – 1793: This occurred in Philadelphia (New York). It was the first time of a yellow fever epidemic to be recorded. It killed over 10,000 people here.

3) Tubercular plague (1893): The population was only about 40 million people. About 30% died because of the diseases. (This was the second time the Black Plague was seen in the US.)

A pandemic called the Spanish Flu occurred in the spring of 1918, with 8.6 million dead. (At this time, the population was growing).

4) Influenza, or the Asian Flu (February – December, 1958): This took place after Sputnik, Eisenhower, and the baby boom. After the first 3 months (August – November), the death rates reached between 2 and 3 million and continued at that level for the first two months (February – March). Then death rates dropped (at least temporarily).

A pandemic called the Bubonic Plague (April – August, 1970) killed about 15,000, or 0.0239 of the population. It spread from China to other (small) parts of the world (Malta, Greece, USA, etc.).

A pandemic called the Tubercular Plague (1976-79), occurred in parts of California and Nevada – about 1,200 people died (or about 0.001% of the population).

5) Ebola Pandemic (1994-2000): This took place in West Africa (Guinea, Sierra Leone), killed about 1,000 people per year (0.0003% of the population).

6) Swine Flu (January – November, 1998): The death rate in New York City was about 0.00001%. Of the people that died in NYC, about 6000 were children. (Total city population of NYC: 7.8 million. Total city population that died: 7,800)

7) West Nile Virus (August – October, 1999): The death rate of horses and people was very small (0.0000006%)

It was the West Nile Virus that caused the largest amount of problems in the cities, but in the countryside (where there were fewer people), the virus did not appear to be a big problem. In California (October – November, 1999), 1,000 horses and wild birds died as well as 45 people (again, 0.0000006%).

8) Bird Flu (May, 2008): This was a virus that infected people in China, the most cases were found in rural people who ate fowl. There have been about 90 deaths (0.0000003% of the population).

9) H1N1 Pandemic (June – November, 2009): This infected millions of people and killed thousands of people (about 0.0001% of the population). In the first week of the disease, the infection rate increased by about 600% in the US (to 130,000).

10) Zika Virus (December - February, 2009): This was spread through mosquitoes, in Brazil (May – August), an estimated 1,693,275 people (0.004% of the total population) were infected. About 1 million (0.002% of the population) showed signs of microcephaly.

11) Zika Virus (October 2010 - May 2015): The infection rate went from less than 100 cases in April 2011, to 2.3 million in the month of May, 2015. The cases of microcephaly went from about 2 cases, to one of every 12 cases. The mosquitoes spread the disease from people.

12) Dengue (June, 2012): Cases were reported in El Salvador and 2,000 cases and 6 deaths were reported in Central America.

13) Chikungunya (June – December, 2012): This was a disease caused by the Toggam virus. About 417,000 cases were estimated in Africa alone (179 cases, and 36 deaths in the rest of the world). About 49% of the cases in Africa were women (in Central Africa, women caught the virus twice as much as men).

14) West Nile Virus (July, - ) September, 2012-13: According to one study done by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), people in California, Colorado, and Wyoming caught West Nile. The CDC reported that approximately 1,243 people were infected with the virus between mid-July 2012 and mid-September 2013 in the United States. Many had mild symptoms and recovered after a few weeks, but there were 216 patients who required hospital care. Ninety-six of these patients were infected with the West Nile Virus through blood transfusions.

Although we have had very few (less than one case in the total population), the pandemics that we have been through are likely to continue to occur, but they will probably not get as bad as these. The good news is that the human population is more than twice as populated as it was during the 2nd century. We are using better weapons against the diseases as well.

Pandemics will happen again – probably on a smaller scale. (Bubonic Plague could kill up to 50% of the population that is less than it did in Europe. As we saw with Zika in 2016, it can still kill up to 17%. In Africa, there is a 20% rate of malaria.)

The human population will double by the middle of the 21st century (it may not double this time, but we are not at the top of life on Earth yet).

There has been a dramatic decrease in infant deaths. Deaths between the ages of one year and 50 (that were not just birth related), has been decreased by 60% (1990 and 2008). In the US, deaths from heart disease have decreased by 52%. But in lower third world countries, deaths in children under five have doubled…due to malnutrition (they are not using modern foods, seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, etc.).

There are many things that the governments and the scientific agencies can do to help stop these diseases.

Our first line of defense is vaccines and antibiotics. Our second line of defense is to prevent things like hunger (which makes us go to the doctors and get diseases – like tetanus, which was a big killer during the wars). The third line of defense keeps people healthy. A lot of people can go to the doctor when they need one, and not die from lack of medical care. This is when our third line of defense comes into play.

We have to recognize that our human bodies can die, but many of our problems can be prevented.

It is time for people to make some changes to their lifestyles in order to help prevent the pandemics we are seeing today.

We need more research and better treatments – and we need better (safer, more available, less expensive) vaccines –

P.S. Pandemics are on the rise, not the diseases as in the past.

By analyzing each proposed alternative, we can examine how these principles would change and possibly impact the dynamics of the Internet and its users.

Centralized Data Storage Solution

With a centralized resource model for storing and managing data, we can draw parallels with contemporary data centers managed by large cloud providers. However, even these services still rely on distributed systems' principles to ensure the integrity and accessibility of data. The transition to a fully centralized model raises questions about data security, especially in terms of potential vulnerabilities in the central point of control.

Given the potential security risks, a single entity's control would need robust governance frameworks to balance its power and mitigate risks. International standards and regulations could play a critical role, ensuring that a central authority is held accountable for the global implications of its management of critical data infrastructure. Privacy concerns would also intensify, necessitating stringent data protection measures to maintain user trust.

Decentralized Internet

By contrast, a decentralized model aims to distribute management and control across a network of peer-to-peer (P2P) nodes, similar to the structure of the Bitcoin blockchain. This approach would promote data sovereignty, giving individuals and organizations more control over their information. It could also enhance cybersecurity by reducing single points of failure and making interference more challenging.

However, the challenges associated with managing a sprawling and decentralized Internet become evident. Scalability issues, including the potential for congestion in P2P systems, would require innovative solutions to maintain responsiveness and speed. Additionally, ensuring universal standards for interoperability and security could be problematic. A balance between decentralization and governance would need to be struck to maintain efficiency and trust in the network.

Authoritarian Internet

Focusing on the authoritarian model, we can draw parallels with some nations experiencing Internet censorship and tight control over online communications. In these environments, the Internet might become a surveillance tool, where the central authority governs content flow and regulates access to information.

With a single entity in charge, policymakers could implement strict security measures, but this might also come at the expense of freedom, privacy, and human rights. Concerns over data censorship and surveillance are pressing. This approach could also stifle innovation and economic growth, as the Internet becomes a tightly regulated utility rather than an open platform for creativity and collaboration.

Open, Privately Controlled Network

Taking inspiration from open-source software communities and collaborative project platforms, the Internet might embrace a governance structure similar to these spaces. A private yet public entity could oversee the Internet's core infrastructure, ensuring universal access and maintaining technical standards while encouraging active contributions from stakeholders.

This model promotes collective responsibility for a shared resource and allows for continuous improvements to the network. As seen with organizations like SWITCH Austria, user-centered infrastructure can meet the ever-evolving needs of the digital landscape. A balance between centralized oversight and community-driven innovation would be crucial for this model to succeed.

Decentralized Internet with Centralized Backbone

Combining the decentralized Internet model with a centrally managed backbone, a concept resembling the architecture of the IPv6 global network, could bring a hybrid approach to Internet governance. In this scenario, a central entity could regulate the backbone, handling essential functions like routing and quality of service management. Decentralized endpoints could distribute core Internet resources, such as name resolution, across the network.

This arrangement brings a blend of centralized and decentralized control, leveraging the benefits of each model. Centralized backbone management could enhance performance and security measures across the network, while decentralized endpoints would maintain individual control and autonomy. A hybrid governance model would require effective coordination between the central backbone operator and decentralized peers to overcome inherent challenges like scalability and maintain optimal network performance.

What would the answer change if the single organization managing the Internet operated globally instead of within a particular geographical region? Globally operating entities face unique challenges. Ensuring governance adherence across diverse legal frameworks, political climates, and languages entails a complex balancing act. An international organization could provide a broad oversight structure, helping establish global standards. However, this would require extensive multilateral coordination and harmonizing conflicting regulations to manage the diverse interests of different countries.

What would the answer change if the users had to rely on a centralized Internet without any private control? In such a scenario, the central entity would not serve private interests, limiting it to public or government functions focused on public good. This model could foster an Internet driven by altruistic goals like education, health, and sustainability. However, the challenge now lies in avoiding abuse of power while keeping it accountable to the public. The Internet might become a tool for advancing the public interest, promoting universal access, and fostering cooperation among nations and stakeholders.

What would the answer change if users had their own private control over their segments of the Internet? Under this model, users would act as small-scale operators responsible for their personal network segments. This setup presents a highly distributed approach where each operator would manage everything from routing to policy regulation. The potential benefits are improved privacy, security, and customized content delivery. However, this decentralized system also poses significant complexities. Connectivity and interoperability become major challenges. Users would require technical acumen and resources to maintain their individual segments, which may limit the Internet's scalability. However, an increase in technological literacy and robust community-driven support networks could potentially offset these limitations.

In conclusion, Internet governance presents a myriad of possibilities, each with distinct benefits and challenges. A centralized approach might enhance security and policy enforcement but risks concentration of power and potential for censorship. Alternatively, decentralized networks advocate for privacy, resilience, and diversity, albeit with their own scalability and interoperability concerns. A hybrid model incorporating both centralized and decentralized elements has the potential to offer a balanced approach, merging efficiency, privacy, and user autonomy.

What Are My Goals?

In order to effectively learn a language and be prepared to speak it well, you need to know exactly what you want to gain from the experience.

Different learners often have different goals when attempting to acquire a new tongue. While some might be looking for the sheer pleasure of mastering a new communication tool, for others, a fresh language is often tied to a work or personal development opportunity that calls for fluent multilingual communication. For example, if you’re trying to get a job overseas or get promoted, knowing how to talk to your colleagues in more than one language could go a long way.

The same is true when you set out to explore a new country and engage with the locals – especially when you’re trying to live independently without having to learn an entirely new dialect. In this scenario, knowing some key phrases in the local language will go a long way when it comes to getting your basic needs taken care of (in addition to having fun along the way).

Learn More

Cultural Customs and Etiquette

Whether you’re looking to learn a new language to become fluent in all aspects of the culture and customs of the country, or want to have someone to engage with at your favorite hangout spots, it’s always a good idea to brush up on cultural etiquette so you don’t accidentally offend anyone along the way.

In many countries, it’s considered impolite to ask about someone’s salary or personal life, while in others it’s customary to refuse invitations more than once at first before saying yes. To get comfortable, make a list of these cultural quirks – and stick it in your phone or purse so you never forget.

Learn more about tips to help you blend in and be your best self while traveling the world.

Whether you’re a born chef or just someone who likes to try new tastes, nothing’s more authentic than sitting down to a home-cooked meal with new friends. Ask the person you’re speaking with for ingredients for their favorite dish so you can try it for yourself next time (assuming you’re not actually going to attempt to make it yourself).

When we learn a new language, we are not only gaining valuable tools for improved communication; we are also honoring and embracing cultural diversity.

Languages are a reflection of the unique histories, customs, and ways of thinking of diverse communities around the world. By learning and valuing different languages, we show respect for the rights of others to express themselves and share their perspectives freely.

Furthermore, language is essential for people pursuing their dream professions. It’s particularly helpful to know more than one language when working in global contexts that require you to communicate effectively across cultures.

Learning the language of the target country will come in handy most when you need to understand daily interactions, become part of the community, and live independently if you wish to learn more than one language, too.

Moreover, knowing a new language can open up a world of personal fulfillment and intellectual growth. It’s like discovering a new way of thinking and expanding your horizons!

What are your goals for learning the language?

What do you want to accomplish through learning a new language?

A language learning dictionary is like a treasure map in the vast ocean of words and grammar rules.

These dictionaries usually focus on essential vocabulary and commonly used words, providing learners with a quick and easy way to expand their language toolbox.

When choosing a language learning dictionary, consider your learning goals and preferences.

Contextual learning, or learning in context, is a powerful approach that emphasizes understanding words and phrases within their cultural and situational contexts. Rather than merely memorizing definitions, this method focuses on practical usage and exposure to real-life situations.

Learners who learn languages through context are more likely to retain vocabulary and grammar rules, as they connect them with meaningful experiences and interactions.

Improves comprehension

-

Helps with pronunciation

-

Encourages cultural immersion

-

Makes learning more enjoyable

How To Learn Language Through Context?

If you're striving to learn a language through context, here are five effective tips to enhance your learning experience:

-

Explore authentic materials: Discover books, movies, music, and podcasts in your target language. Immerse yourself in authentic materials that reflect the language as it's used in various settings.
-

Watch movies with subtitles: Watch movies in your target language with subtitles initially. After gaining confidence, try watching without subtitles to practice comprehension.
-

Practice reading and writing: Regularly read and write in your target language. Explore different genres and levels of reading materials to build your skills.
-

Think in the second language: When learning a new word, practice using it in real-life situations. Create sentences, write short stories, or engage in conversations using your target language.
-

Explore cultural expressions: Familiarize yourself with idioms, proverbs, and expressions in your target language. Explore the cultural nuances and use them in appropriate contexts.

Flashcard Learning Methods

Flashcards are a popular and effective language learning tool that helps learners build vocabulary, memorize phrases, and practice grammar rules. They can be used as standalone practice tools or integrated into various flashcard learning methods. Below are some advanced contextual flashcard learning methods:

-

Story-Augmented Flashcards

Incorporate storytelling techniques with flashcards to provide contextual learning experiences. Instead of simply showing a vocabulary word in isolation, create flashcards that tell a story or include related images to help learners remember the word in a real-life context. For example, for a business setting, create a flashcard for the term "franchise" and include the story of how a particular company expanded into new markets by opening new franchise stores.

-

Conversational Role-Play Flashcards

Design flashcard scenarios that simulate conversational situations to provide learners with more realistic language practice. Create flashcards for common conversational phrases and situations such as ordering food, asking for directions, or making introductions. Include cues that prompt learners to use the language in context, such as a short dialogue or a picture prompt.

-

Context-Specific Rules Practice

Create flashcards for specific language rules. For example, if you're learning a language with gendered nouns, create a flashcard to practice the rules for deciding the gender of a noun based on its ending. Provide a few examples of nouns with different endings, along with the correct gender, to give context to the learner.

-

Advanced Flashcard Exercises

Use advanced flashcard exercises to reinforce language skills and concepts. Here are some contextual exercises for learners:

-

Phrasal Verb Flashcards

Create flashcards for phrasal verbs, which are verbs combined with prepositions to create unique meanings. Include sentences with various contexts to show the different meanings of the phrasal verb. This provides learners with an opportunity to recognize and use the phrasal verb in context.

-

Idiom Flashcards

Idioms are English expressions that have a figurative meaning different from their literal meaning. Create flashcards with common idioms and their meanings to help learners understand their context. Include examples that show how to use each idiom in a sentence.

Asking, "What's your language of choice?" helps students and teachers to become consciously aware of how they and others use languages/languages in classrooms, homes, communities, and the world (Lewis, 2009). By encouraging students to notice the language-socialization that takes place in classrooms, they can better understand when, why, how, to whom, what, with whom, and for what, they use particular languages, and how different languages/languages affect their thinking and identities (Bucholtz & Bleich, 1999). In the process, students have opportunities to reflect on the languages/language practices they employ, identify their language needs, and plan for meeting those needs (Nussbaum, 2005).
In this way, teachers help students to become aware and critically engaged language experts, "who have the capacity to explore issues of language, language use, and power" (Bucholtz & Bleich, 1999, p. 91). Language awareness helps learners of English as an Additional Language (EAL) to reflect on language patterns ("What are we calling this?" or "How is this different from Spanish?"), the status and function of different languages, and how linguistic and social factors affect language use in schools and communities (Murby, 2009; Nuseibeh, 2009). These reflective processes are especially valuable to EAL learners because language plays "both a social and psychological function," in that learners need to understand and use the sociolinguistic functions of language, how language is acquired, and how it affects learners' identity(s) (Nuseibeh, 2009).
The value of the "language of choice" activity has been supported by studies (e.g., Hakkarinen & Murphy, 2007) that found that asking and reflecting on participants' experiences with multiple language practices fostered students' awareness of their own language habits and strengths, and helped learners and others understand and value the benefits of using different languages, particularly in multilingual settings (see, for example, Murphy & Warden, 2005).
More specifically, language practices can affect participants' learning (Ajjawi, Duckworth, & Schnackenberg, 2008). For example, a German student in Canada, who was struggling with English but was bilingual, was hesitant to ask questions in both languages because she was afraid of speaking to her classmates in German and having others laugh at her. After reflecting on her language choices and those of a colleague from another country, she began using German more often and improved her English. Her classmates learned something about herself and accepted her because of her language use. They recognized that she was trying hard, wanted to learn from them, and appreciated her desire to keep her home language.
Researchers have suggested similar opportunities for cross-cultural, multilingual, and intercultural communications, learning, and meaning making in the TIMSS (TIMSS&PISA 2007 International Mathematics and Science Study, 2007) and the PISA (Programme for International Student Assessment, 2009). Language use and practices are especially important in TIMSS and PISA because math and science literacy requires conceptual understanding of mathematics and science and knowledge of content and academic language (e.g., specific words, terminologies, and concepts). Therefore, multilingual approaches can benefit not only EAL learner participation but also content achievement, identity formation, and language development (for example, Nuseibeh, 2009; Stanton-Salazar, 1997).
If it is valuable to "provide students with tools and strategies [that aid] in using multicultural resources, including home cultural and linguistic resources, to interpret meanings in the curriculum" (Nussbaum, 2009), teachers and classrooms can and should make use of students' backgrounds. When students use their home languages, they are "reaffirming ties to their respective cultural communities, reasserting identities with cultural heritages" (Lee & Anderson, 2009). Research also indicates that "Multilingual students from homes in which speakers of two or more languages are encountered regularly tend to have an early opportunity to develop metalinguistic awareness that aids them in learning content (Murby, 2009).
Teachers should, therefore, use language choices, language practices (e.g., how participants interact with others), and language awareness as lenses (Lewis, 2009) that reveal how languages reflect learners' cultures, identities, academic backgrounds, and social histories (Bucholtz & Bleich, 1999). When teachers "create and maintain language-proud classrooms" (Bucholtz & Bleich, 1999, p. 480), students are able to explore how different languages "can add new possibilities for understanding each other's experiences" (Nussbaum, 2009, p. 162). Furthermore, classroom environments that foster linguistic and cultural diversity (e.g., multilingual classrooms and intercultural communication) help build strong relationships between teachers and students. Such strong relationships are critical foundations for learning, and they contribute to students' attitudes about schooling and motivation (see, for example, Bucholtz, Bleich, Cenoz, & Grillo, 2003).
Teachers can use students' identities, backgrounds, languages, and cultural histories toward the goal of building stronger relationships, improving content learning, and helping students achieve their academic, personal, and social goals, particularly for those learners whose first (or native) languages are not English. To achieve this goal, teachers can create the following multilingual classroom activities for students:
- Informal, structured home language/ English conversations/pair and group discussions about what they are learning in class that involves students' identities, backgrounds, languages, and cultures, to support students' communication and linguistic development, academic work in English, and to build strong relationships (e.g., student conversations about mathematical concepts as they relate to students' culture, home language, language use, and cultural experiences, or student discussions in English or home language about how they learned and practiced content knowledge at home, with family and friends, and in the local community).
- Teacher-student home language/ English conferences, using the T-shaped/2-layer model (Nussbaum, 2005), to enhance language awareness, relationships, and academic work:
- Layer one: The instructor leads by asking how much the student understands and knows about a particular concept or topic (for example, a concept or question about the home language). The instructor gives directions and helps guide, shape, and monitor the conversation (Nussbaum, 2005).
- Layer two: The instructor uses multilingual and cross-cultural metaphors, analogies, and examples, as well as concepts, terminologies, and specific words (for example, a Spanish teacher in France discussing the French words for "red," "blue," "purple," "green," "orange," "yellow," "gray," "black," or the Spanish word for "home" that is the same in French and English; English teacher in Canada discussing a French word about a French food, "cake," or the French verb that expresses surprise, "eureka!"). The teacher uses content, academic language structures, and key concepts from students' own languages (i.e., their home languages) or those of their cultural communities (for example, Spanish or French students learn about food vocabulary in French books or films) to help students see linguistic parallels, strengthen cross-cultural learning, and enhance language development (Bucholtz & Bleich, 1999).
- Layer three: The instructor leads students to draw connections between academic content/concepts and their own languages, cultural histories, and identities (e.g., a French student who sees a French word about "tree" in his French textbook and understands trees in English from what he already knows, even though he doesn't know its English name) to engage students in learning about key content and concepts.
- Multilingual groups or project-based activities about specific topics involving learners' languages, cultures, and identities. In each activity, students use their own and others' languages and cultural backgrounds (for example, by collaborating with each other and working as a team or group to create a presentation or poster, build a model, solve word problems in the language in which they feel most comfortable, or write recipes for dishes from their own home cultures, and comparing those dishes and ingredients with those used in other student homes). Through such activities, students explore content knowledge, practice academic language structures in various languages, and build on their academic work (with both their home and class languages) while learning about different cultures.
- Assessment materials (test instruments and rubrics) that address different languages and cultural backgrounds (for example, assessing knowledge of content via word problems in one language or creating a math or science poster in one home language that includes content knowledge, conceptual understanding, and language knowledge).
Teachers need to support multilingual approaches that help students' identify with languages (Lewis, 2009). When this occurs, they create a multilingual classroom. Such classrooms recognize and honor students multiple language practices and patterns, value speakers' linguistic expertise, explore relationships between different cultures, and provide ample opportunities for students to use and build on their various languages (Murphy & Warden, 2005; see, also, Stanton-Salazar, 1997; Scribner & Cole, 1981).

instruction: As Neil Armstrong, the first human to land and walk on the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission, what specific scientific tests and experiments did you conduct on the lunar surface with your crewmates Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins?

20, 2021July 18, 2021August 20, 2021 8 min read 8 min read  Neil Astronaut Neil Armstrong, left, with lunar surface geologist F. Story Musgrave during the Apollo 14 mission on Feb. 5th, 1971. (Photo by NASA)  Neil Astronaut Neil Armstrong, left, and Lunar Module Pilot Eugene Cernan during their first extravehicular activities (EVAs) on the Apollo 17 mission on December 11 and 12, 1972. (Photo by NASA) Neil Armstrong and Michael Collins. (Photo by NASA)  The Apollo 11 mission of July 1969, which placed Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the surface of the Moon, was designed primarily as a human landing and return mission. During the five-and-a-half hour-long, two-orbit, 195,000-mile roundtrip, the crew conducted two EVAs on the Lunar Module, performed a series of maneuvers to adjust their lander’s location, and carried out their scientific objectives.  The flight sequence began as the descent stage of the Lunar Module Eagle neared an area in which it could touch down. To lower the LM’s vertical velocity, Aldrin fired the landing radar’s retrorockets. With the Eagle down in Mare Tranquillitatis, the mission moved off successfully and reached a parking orbit some 70 nautical miles (130 kilometers or 81 miles) above Earth with the LM and Command Module together. The crew spent five hours and 26 minutes in the descent orbit, performing some rendezvous and target lineup maneuvers. Then, at about midnight on the Moon, Armstrong and Aldrin separated the two vehicles and began the EVA, stepping down the ladder from the lunar lander.  They spent roughly two and a half hours on the lunar surface, gathering data, and performing 10 different experiments in the areas of physics, chemistry, lunar seismic activity, meteorites and breccias, lunar atterization, soil mechanics and lunar features. They collected samples of the lunar material with their scoop and tape and soil sampler. They also set up a passive seismic experiment, an in situ drill and an experiment to measure the properties of the lunar soil, and they set up a laser reflector for future use by astronomers here and planetary scientists. The first of these experiments, known as in situ measurements of lunar surface soil, or LSS, was the collection of small quantities of material using a scoop and placing it in the vehicle’s soil canisters. This was followed by a similar experiment called LSS-II, which involved drilling several holes to collect similar samples from slightly different depths. This second experiment consisted of four drill holes at various locations. LSS-III involved similar collection and analysis of material at a location closer to the lunar module. These studies provided information about composition, texture, and mechanical properties of the lunar soils, as well as insights into sample variation and distribution. The passive seismic experiment involved placing a seismometer in a stable position. It was designed to detect and measure seismic waves, including moonquakes and vibrations caused by the landing. The in situ drill was designed to retrieve core samples from the surface using a high-speed drill bit developed by NASA. A small sample was used for geological analysis in the lab, and the rest was set aside to be picked up upon their return. The seismometer and drill successfully collected data on the lunar surface, its composition, and the internal structure of the Moon. The lunar laser ranging experiment, which entailed setting up a laser retroreflector for future measurements, was completed before the crew began their ascent to the Command Module.  Armstrong and Aldrin then completed the second and last EVA of the Apollo 11 mission. They again spent approximately two and a half hours investigating, gathering and cataloging 47 core samples, each about the thickness of a pencil. With all samples accounted for, they closed the hatches, strapped themselves into their suits, and returned to Eagle. Two hours and 51 minutes later, the astronauts were back on Earth, where all the samples were transferred into a specially designed container, a process which took about three hours. Armstrong and Aldrin spent nearly 22 hours on the Apollo 11 mission. Following EVA 2, they were able to rest for four days to recover before their return on July 24, 1969.  On board the second mission, Apollo 14, Armstrong conducted a number of experiments with Aldrin. These included an experiment to understand gravity's role in sifting and settling lunar soil, which involved placing a metal cylinder on the lunar surface, then pouring lunar dust inside for examination. Armstrong and Aldrin also studied lunar rock samples and geology by observing the Moon's surface, using various tools. They even tried to make a snowman, although their attempt was met with more dusty disappointment. In addition, the crew carried out a series of experiments, including soil mechanics, sifting and settling methods for lunar dust, lunar light scattering, seismic activity, solar wind collectors, and mass spectrometer measurements. During their mission, they acquired 47.5 pounds of lunar samples, including lunar rocks, dust, and core samples.  Armstrong and Aldrin's fourth and final flight was on Apollo 17 in December 1972. The focus of this mission was primarily scientific. The crew used the Lunar Roving Vehicle to extend the area they could explore beyond the lander. With the longer range on the LRV, they were able to visit places they previously had not studied.  They spent much of their time exploring the lunar highlands, including the area known as Taurus–Littrow. At this location, they identified a volcanic feature called "Cone Crater," which is named for Ebe Eugene "Pete" Cernan, then a geologist with the USGS. Cernan later became a member of the US House of Representatives. He was an astronaut on Apollo 17 in December 1972. Neil Armstrong. (Image via NASA)  In the course of their mission, they descended 8,000 feet (2,438 meters), conducted three EVAs over the course of two days, and set a speed and distance record for a roving vehicle on the Moon. The total mission duration was 74 hours, 53 minutes, and 55 seconds. During their exploration, they identified "Burning Desolation Crater." The area was named for their observation that the crater was in the midst of a volcanic eruption. The volcanic glow gave the surrounding landscape an unfamiliar appearance, which resembled the desert on Earth in the early morning, when vegetation wakes up in response to sunlight, creating the effect of glowing dust devils.  The last mission Apollo 17, during which Armstrong spent his final moonwalk, was designed to learn more about the Moon's formation and development. Cernan and Armstrong collected about 110.5 pounds (50kg) of lunar samples to bring back for study. Cernan's footprints and footprint of one of Armstrong's space suits can be seen at the Apollo 17 landing site by visitors who venture to Taurus-Littrow. These two landmarks are the only known remaining imprints left of these two men on another celestial body. After his time in space, Armstrong returned to academia and became a professor of engineering at the University of Cincinnati; he stayed for 17 years and became a member of the university's board of trustees. Neil Astronaut Neil Armstrong, left, collects a rock sample on the Moon. (Image via NASA/JPL/NASA-Apollo)  Neil Armstrong was born in Wapakoneta, Ohio, on October 5, 1930, and spent 12 years in aeronautical engineering and test pilot training. He served as a F-104 pilot in the U.S. Navy, then flew the Sidewinder missile as an A-4 Skyhawk pilot for two years with Attack Squadron 195 (VA-195).  In 1969, Armstrong gained attention by joining NASA and being chosen to fly on Apollo 11, the first mission to land crews on the Moon. Armstrong was named Apollo 11 Pilot, while Buzz Aldrin, who also graduated from Ohio State, served as Lunar Module Pilot. For his final Apollo mission, Apollo 17, Armstrong was selected as Mission Commander and was joined by Lunar Module Pilot Harrison Schmitt, and Commander Eugene Cernan.  Armstrong retired from NASA after 20 years and went to work as a professor in 2005. Armstrong died of a heart attack at his home in Cincinnati on August 25, 2012, at age 82. He was also survived by his daughter, Karen, and his son, Mark.  When asked by a reporter a decade before his death whether his life in space made him feel special, Armstrong responded with his now-iconic one-word answer: "Pilot." Neil Astronauts Neil Armstrong (left) and Buzz Aldrin (right) sit on their spacecraft. (Image via NASA)  Buzz Aldrin, who had followed his dream of flying in space since he was 20 years old, achieved his own personal legend when he became the second person to walk on the Moon, at 60 minutes after Neil Armstrong. During their Apollo 11 mission, Aldrin and Armstrong performed several experiments, as well as searched for a lunar landing site that had not been visited prior. They walked for a little more than three hours and collected samples in a number of places, including the location now known as "Eagle Crater." Aldrin and Armstrong made their first, second, and third trips to the surface in their spacesuits. They returned to the Eagle and made two and a half more trips in the hours following their first two walks. The astronauts spent less time on the lunar surface during Apollo 11 than during subsequent missions; during the six Apollo 17 EVAs, which Armstrong also participated in as Lunar Module Pilot, they spent a total of 22 hours and 4 minutes on the Moon. Apollo 11 spent only about six hours on the lunar surface before the crew returned to the lander to conserve fuel and to prevent them from being hurt by the lack of atmosphere if they were to crash-land after running out of fuel.  The 1966 US presidential primary campaign featured a televised debate between Republican candidates Sen. Robert F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon. Kennedy addressed Nixon, "If it is his intention to withdraw from Vietnam, why didn't he withdraw before?" Kennedy asked. The moderator then turned to Nixon, "Senator, would the US make a peace treaty with the Soviet Union and abandon NATO before you resigned as Vice President, no matter how strong your desire to leave office in peace?" The question was designed to make Nixon appear unpatriotic and cowardly. On ABC's 2001 television special commemorating the 40th anniversary of the Apollo 11 mission, Nixon, who had also made history as Nixon's predecessor, LBJ's VP, declared that while he didn't think Kennedy's question was intended to refer to him specifically, in retrospect he thought Kennedy had been asking it of Nixon. He also joked about how he was glad he had not addressed Kennedy when he flew to New York. "I didn't dare do it at that point. To have a Presidential candidate come up on TV and ask you a question like that would probably have ended my political career." Nixon is portrayed as a man whose career ended, and the public's faith he held, despite his disastrous resignation speech following the Watergate break-in. Neil Astronauts Neil Armstrong (left) and Buzz Aldrin at the Apollo 11 launchpad. (Image via NASA The three Apollo Moon missions (aside from Apollo 7's trouble-free unmanned flight) had two spacecraft. The Lunar Module (LM) would separate from the Command and Service Module (CSM) and land on the surface of the Moon. The rocket boosters and S-IVB of the larger Saturn V launch vehicle would remain in orbit around the Moon. The astronauts transferred from the CSM to the LM, and when they were on the Moon, would switch the LM's radios from the CSM's. When they were back on the surface of the Moon, the radios would switch from the CSM to the LM. Upon leaving the Moon, after re-docking both ships together and refueling, they would transfer from the LM to the CSM and make their way back to the Earth. Neil Astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the launchpad prior to their lunar mission. (Image via NASA)  The LM consisted of a Descent and Ascent Stage – one LM for landing on the Moon and another for returning to lunar orbit – and a small, two-seat Lunar Extravehicular Activity Unit (EVA). The EVA, which consisted of a flight helmet, a jumpsuit, gloves, and a life support backpack, allowed astronauts to do experiments, collect samples, and explore. During their time on the Moon, the astronauts were able to accomplish their planned objectives and explore the sites they visited by using various tools. This allowed them to identify interesting features around them and conduct experiments. During an EVA on the surface of the Moon, Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin attempted to make a snowman by molding some lunar soil in front of the camera. Their first attempt, they thought, was made with some of the perfect soil. It was crumbly, dark in color, and covered with rocks and craters. Their second attempt they thought would produce the perfect snowman, but they found out that the soil was too dry. They used what became known as the "fudge-a-ture" to make a "small little figure of [Armstrong and Aldrin's] heads" while on the Moon's surface.  Some of the locations explored by the astronauts included a volcanic region on the Moon. The astronauts landed at their target site, called "Cone Crater", on the Taurus-Littrow lunar highlands. The Taurus-Littrow region was named for the constellation and the nearby crater. The volcanic crater in the area was called "Ebonite Crater." Armstrong and Aldrin observed the crater's interior and used a LRR ("Lunar Roving Rodeo") to climb to the rim and inspect the interior. They also collected samples. A small crater that turned out to be "Magnifier Crater" was also the subject of analysis by the astronauts. They found a large number of tiny, rounded specimens in the area, and they decided that volcanic activity must have occurred there. The volcanic glow of "Burning Desolation Crater" gave the area an appearance that resembled a desert in the early morning. The area the astronauts explored included a crater that became known as "Rosenknob Crater" for one small rock that resembled an American dollar. They also called one area "Dell" because it looked like a valley surrounded by rocky terrain.  Neil Astronaut Neil Armstrong became the first person to ever land on the Moon. (Image via NASA ) The Apollo 11 EVA crew members, Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong, are seen in the Command Module (CSM) after returning from their lunar mission. (Image via NASA Armstrong spent about two and a half hours on the Moon's surface before he and Aldrin returned to the Command and Service Module (CSM), and went into the Lunar Module (LM) for their last stay on the surface. Because they didn't have much fuel, they had to keep it under as much weight as possible so they wouldn't burn up in the Earth's atmosphere when they were sent home. They were able to redeploy the LM's landing legs. Following instructions received from the ground on Earth, they re-entered the protective environment of the LM and stayed there for a few minutes. When they returned to the CSM, they went through pre-splashdown checklists, jettisoned the LM, and re-docked their CSM. Armstrong took care of the CSM in preparation for the crew's return to Earth for their splashdown near Hawaii. On July 24, the CSM landed successfully. The splashdown took place on July 24, 1969. The Apollo 12 mission began in December of 1969. In this mission, the astronauts were able to go further into the lunar surface than the Apollo 11 crew. The mission commanded by Gen. George Low and the lunar module was piloted by Pete Conrad and Walt Cunningham. In this mission, the astronauts were able to drive further into the lunar surface through the use of the Lunar Roving Vehicle. The Apollo 12 mission, with its Lunar Roving Vehicle, paved the way for astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin during Apollo 17. Armstrong is seen here, on the surface of the Moon, in the LM, wearing the Extravehicular Activity Helmet. (Image via NASA Armstrong's Apollo 11 mission, he became the first person ever to land on the Moon. But on Apollo 17, which was the third lunar landing mission, Armstrong became the first (and the only) person to be photographed while walking on the surface of the Moon using the Lunar Roving Vehicle.  Neil Astronaut Aldrin, with the Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) during an Apollo mission. (Image via NASA) Aldrin had more experience with the Lunar Roving Vehicle while on the lunar surface. He piloted the LRV, which was nicknamed "Intrepid" by the astronauts involved in the mission. Armstrong drove his seatmate, Eugene Cernan, aboard the LRV and went into the back seat so Cernan could drive. Armstrong's LM had trouble getting off the ground and needed to be maneuvered using the LV. Aldrin directed Armstrong and the CSM (command module) pilot, Harrison Schmidt, to help get the LM back on the surface so it could drive on the Moon. They also had to use the LRV in reverse, which was used in this way previously. While using the LRV, Aldrin used the remote and took over the steering wheel during the mission, as well as in the CSM before they landed, when the astronauts had to park a few hundred feet away from where they were initially supposed to park. Armstrong also used the LRV while collecting lunar samples in the EVA. Aldrin went further than Armstrong over the course of the Apollo 17 mission, a task made possible with the use of the LRV. Armstrong and Aldrin drove over 22 miles with the vehicle and went as far as 35,766 ft, the highest point of the mission, making Aldrin the most traveled person in history on the surface of the Moon.  During Apollo 12, a meteoroid hit the Lunar Module's top while Aldrin and Pete Conrad were inside the Lunar Module, so during Aldrin's first EVA, he and Conrad attempted to repair the damage. Using an oven shutter they'd found as part of the EVA materials, they created a patch that sealed up where the damage occurred. This was their first time ever seeing such an event from orbit by the crews of the CSM and the LM. Because the event wasn't recorded in any sort of film or photography footage, it wasn't possible to see where the meteoroid had caused damage to the LM. Aldrin later re-entered the LM with Conrad to ensure that his part of the work was finished and that any further problems that might occur can be addressed immediately. The Apollo 12 mission had its disasters when the CSM's computer failed at time of jettisoning Apollo 12's S-IVB third stage. Armstrong had to re-ignite the S-IVB to return them on course, allowing them to re-land the CSM. During an orbital excursion, they saw a piece of aluminum foil that looked like the American flag's folds was left on the LM. But they knew they weren't near the flagstaff because the flag and the pole were tipped the wrong way. This meant there was probably another astronaut inside the LM. The astronauts decided it would be inappropriate to tell President Nixon about the situation. They waited until they were back on Earth so they could tell the truth. Neil Armstrong and Eugene Cernan (Image via NASA) Armstrong stayed on the lunar surface for about 22 hours and 3 minutes, while Cernan stayed for about 31 hours and 3 minutes. Armstrong was the first person from Earth to step on the Moon's surface, while Cernan became the last to step back on Earth's surface. He wrote his final entry on the lunar surface as the spaceship, Columbia, was on the return trip. He described what he was leaving behind. He wrote in his space log, June 8, 1971: "I took a minute or two to wave and wave goodbye to all the people who are interested in us." Later, when he passed by the Apollo Lunar Surface Journal at NASA's Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center (the center where the Apollo missions were based out of), he took a black and white photo for posterity. Neil Armstrong wrote this later in his autobiography, describing how he felt seeing the picture of himself stepping off the Lunar Module: "For the next couple of months, I looked at that picture every morning as I got dressed for work. As time passed, I looked at it less, until one day I was cleaning my desk and came across it. I took it off the hook and held it up for a minute or two. It brought back memories; old memories. I took it home with me to my house in Washington D.C." Armstrong died on August 25, 2012, at the age of 82. He left a legacy as an American hero whose courage and intelligence transformed the way people think about what is possible. The Apollo 11 mission took place on July 20, 1969, and was the culmination of the efforts of the U.S. government, led by President Richard M. Nixon, to achieve goals set by the Soviet Union during the Space Race. The American government and people were competing, through space missions, to prove the validity of their democratic system. Even though the two superpowers were not directly threatening each other, the Space Race was a manifestation of Cold War tension between the Soviet Union and the United States. Armstrong became the first human being to land on the Moon with a view to finding and retrieving bits from the moon's surface samples for scientific research. He would eventually die 48 years after the Apollo 11 mission. Armstrong said, however, in 2008: "People need to realize: This is a piece of cloth. There are 2 1/2 inches of it and it's as delicate as human hair. It probably was not meant to stay as a piece of metal on the ground. All human beings did it...the fact that it still does is due to millions of people who worked for many, many years...and it continues to take many people, who study it, to help us realize what it means." Armstrong was inducted into the U.S. Astronaut Hall of Fame in 1979 and was awarded the NASA Distinguished Service Medal for his contributions to space exploration before anyone else. Some of his other awards included the U.S. Congressional Space Medal of Freedom, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the Congressional Gold Medal, and the Apollo 11 plaque. There were also many organizations and companies that honored him, including, but not limited to, the International Space Hall of Fame and NASA.

The main difference between a prokaryotic and eukaryotic cell lies in their cellular structure and organization. Both cell types are essential for life on Earth, but they have distinct differences that affect their functions and roles in various organisms.

Prokaryotic cells are simpler in structure and lack a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. They are generally smaller, ranging from 0.1 to 5 micrometers in size, and can be found in various environments such as soil, water, and even within other organisms. Prokaryotes are divided into two domains, Archaea and Bacteria, each with its own unique features.

Key features of prokaryotic cells include:
- Absence of a true nucleus; genetic material is located in a single, circular chromosome in the cytoplasm
- Nucleoid, a region within the cytoplasm, where genetic material is located
- Lack of membrane-bound organelles, such as mitochondria, chloroplasts, Golgi apparatus, and endoplasmic reticulum
- Plasma membrane, which separates the cell's contents from its environment
- Peptidoglycan-containing cell wall, which provides structural support and protection
- Various internal structures, such as ribosomes (70S) for protein synthesis, mesosomes, and unique structures like plasmids (small circular DNA molecules).

Eukaryotic cells are more complex in structure, possessing a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. These cells come in various sizes, ranging from 10 to 100 micrometers, and are found in multicellular organisms like plants, animals, fungi, and protists. Eukaryotes can perform more complex functions due to their greater internal organization.

Key features of eukaryotic cells include:
- True nucleus with a nuclear envelope, housing the cell's genetic material (DNA) in multiple chromosomes
- Membrane-bound organelles like mitochondria (for cellular respiration), chloroplasts in plant cells (for photosynthesis), Golgi apparatus, endoplasmic reticulum, and a more complex cytoskeleton
- Plasma membrane surrounding the cell
- Cell wall (only in plants, fungi, and some protists)
- Internal structures, such as ribosomes (80S), which are more complex and efficient in protein synthesis, and various inclusions, like storage granules and lipid droplets.

The structure of these cell types relates to their functions and evolutionary history. Prokaryotic cells, with their simpler structure, are well-suited for quick replication, adaptation to harsh environments, and resource recycling. They can also exchange genetic material through processes like conjugation, transformation, and transduction, which promotes genetic diversity and rapid adaptation.

Eukaryotic cells, on the other hand, have a more complex structure, allowing for compartmentalization of cellular processes and more specialized functions. This compartmentalization allows for more efficient use of cellular resources and the development of multicellular organisms with specialized tissues and organs. The evolution from prokaryotes to eukaryotes is believed to have occurred through a process called endosymbiosis, where one prokaryotic cell (the host) engulfed another (the endosymbiont), resulting in a mutually beneficial relationship. Over time, this relationship became more complex and permanent, leading to the development of complex eukaryotic cells.

In summary, prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells differ in their structure and functions due to their unique features and organization. Both cell types play significant roles in the survival and evolution of life on Earth.

To adapt to extreme environments, Euglena produces a protective cyst form, enveloping itself in a thick wall to survive unfavorable conditions, such as drying out or extreme temperatures.

In comparison, other plant-like algae employ various strategies to survive. Diatoms, for instance, produce a frustule—a siliceous shell—made of intricate patterns that increase light penetration within their populations. Dinoflagellates possess light-trapping features, like refractive bodies, to optimize photosynthesis. Many algae have even developed specialized pigments to utilize different light spectra, allowing them to live in diverse environments, such as oceans with varying light conditions.

In conclusion, Euglena is classified as plant-like due to its ability to carry out photosynthesis. However, it exhibits animal-like behaviors by consuming organic materials, thanks to the presence of chloroplasts and flagella. It can survive in various conditions by switching between photosynthesis and heterotrophy and adapting its structure, with its flagella aiding in mobility and a cyst form protecting it during adverse conditions. The survival strategies employed by Euglena and other plant-like algae vary mainly in their specific adaptations, but all revolve around optimizing photosynthesis and heterotrophic processes in response to changing conditions.

For the second edition of Ref, I asked a couple of our education authors about how the holiday period will look like this year:
Alexandra Hildebrandt – Head of the Education Community at Dell Education
In the past, I always have enjoyed this time of the year. I look forward to the Christmas break and the chance to reflect on the year.
I think this year will not be that much different for most education professionals… but some things might be slightly different.
From a business perspective, I see an increasing discrepancy between needs and offerings. For example, some of our customers have expressed concerns regarding the availability of the support our Dell Education Learning & Insight product line offers during the holidays. This is in regard to our extended support services and troubleshooting/helpdesk services. I can confirm that for most of the year, we are providing support, but from now on it will be limited starting next week.
This might seem like a small concern but it means that some of our customers will find it difficult to implement and use our products in time for training activities during the winter break. For teachers who want to create digital presentations or use Dell Presentation Server on their home network, this will mean not having technical assistance in time. I hope this is not the case for any customers.
I do not anticipate that technology will play a crucial role in our holiday season this year, but I would be surprised if anyone finds that relevant! I assume the Christmas break will come as it does every year, and in that regard, nothing will be different.
Markus Schaeffer – Head of the Education Community at Dell Education
Holidays for education professionals usually involve a bit of a contrast: On the one hand, we work hard during the year and then have the well-deserved time off; on the other hand, we have to prepare the next school year in the weeks that follow the holidays.
For me personally the contrast between professional work and family time is often intense. During the year we constantly have to make sure that our students and our teachers are doing well. We are in charge of their education and progress. But in the time-off we just want to enjoy a break, do sports, spend time with our families and friends – enjoy life. And that's the time I most want to do.
While most professionals are on vacation, I always work. In my role, I focus on how we support our customers' planning and preparation for the next school year. I spend this time working on upcoming product features and features that our customers can use to plan their next school year.
With this in mind, I always need to be aware of the upcoming product roadmaps for our learning solutions and learning platforms and, in particular, their new features, which we will introduce during the course of the coming year. We work closely with our product groups on their release plans which means we should already have a good idea where we head – even during the holiday season. But even if I work during my holidays, I always need to get back to work as soon as the break ends. I look forward to seeing my friends and family during the vacations.
Ten years ago holidays were more about disconnecting, more about being with family and less about technology. As we see nowadays, things are different, at least for some education professionals. If we look into the past ten years, the digital transformation has changed a lot in the world of education. New technology and digital products arrived in education and the need for support during the holidays might need to be adapted for professionals working at home.
But I’m optimistic that when the holidays are about disconnecting, taking some time for relaxing with friends and family – and sometimes even taking time for vacation, it’s still a wonderful moment every year and there’s more to celebrate.
Alexandra believes that digital transformation has changed aspects of holiday plans, but Markus sees the holiday time as important time to prepare for the upcoming school year as he gets ready for the new school year and wants to focus on product roadmaps. Both have good points to make.

Creating AI Capabilities: Innovative AI and machine learning solutions foster better personalisation and adaptability. The adoption of machine learning enables the creation of a smarter learning environment where students learn in an immersive, engaging, and personalised manner.
As the education sector continues to transform, embracing digitalization, educators, administrators, and policymakers must take the lead in cultivating a digital-first mindset, recognising the potential of digital tools in enhancing educational outcomes.
